clues.text: "It's not unusual" for female fans to pelt this singer of "Delilah" with room keys & panties
"Losing My Religion" is a hit by this Michael Stipe band
In a 1991 top 5 hit, Bonnie Raitt sang, "Let's give them" this, later the title of a Julia Roberts-Dennis Quaid movie
In the '80s this band had hits like "A View to a Kill" & "The Wild Boys"; in the '90s, "Come Undone" & "Ordinary World"

This group had its initial success in 1991, hitting No. 1 with the following

"Your purple prose just gives you away /
The things, you say /
You're unbelievable"
Born in Blue Ridge Summit, PA., the duchess was raised in this "Birthplace of the Star-Spangled Banner"
A famous quote attributed to the Duchess of Windsor is "One can never be too rich or too" this
On January 4, 1937, this U.S. magazine chose the future Duchess of Windsor as its "Woman of the Year" for 1936
On June 3, 1937 the duke & duchess married at the Chateau de Cande near Tours in this country
Last name of the duchess' second husband, a London shipbroker
In 1916 G. N. Lewis proposed that atoms in a molecule bond by sharing a pair of these particles
Boiling a liquid, condensing the vapor, boilng that liquid, etc. is called the "fractional" type of this process
This letter & number precede SO<sub>4</sub> in the formula for sulfuric acid
In 1923 Bronsted & Lowry figured out that these substances donate protons to bases
Enthalpy, a thermodynamic property of a substance, is abbreviated H, for this

rounds.comments: (Alex: You identify the instrument most associated with the person I will name.)

clues.text: Buddy Rich
Stan Getz
Lionel Hampton
Pete Fountain
Charlie Mingus
3,000 of these Hebrew coins in silver were equivalent to one silver talent
Also called a zecchino, it was a gold coin of the Venetian republic; now it's a shiny ornamental disk seen on gowns
The U.S. quarter is sometimes called "two bits" because this Spanish peso was once cut into fourths
This Roman coin was the penny mentioned in the New Testament: its name means "containing ten"
This coin of Florence, Italy became the standard of trade throughout Europe from the 1200s to the 1400s
"Kremlin Chimes" is the second play in Nikolai Pogodin's trilogy about this leader of the Russian Revolution
This Canadian province's famous Shaw Festival focuses on plays by George Bernard Shaw & his contemporaries
This "Martin Chuzzlewit" novelist not only co-wrote the play "The Frozen Deep", he acted in it, too
Ichimura Manjiro is a famous Onnagata, a male actor who plays female roles in this form of Japanese drama
This "Electra"fying playwright gets the credit for adding a third actor to Greek tragedies
For warmth, the horseshoe species of these will cluster in groups in the roofs of caves
It's Asia's great red ape
The largest land carnivores are a couple of species of this mammal
Bluefins are tuna; blues & fins are these mammals
Besides its own species of penguin & tortoise, this island group has its own species of mammal--a fur seal
This author's techno-thriller "Rainbow Six" focuses on John Clark, also a hero in "Clear & Present Danger"
This author made a University of Virginia law professor the protagonist of his 2002 novel "The Summons"
You were born to identify this author of "The Bourne Identity"
"The Numa Files" are paperback spin-offs of this writer's novels featuring Dirk Pitt
"The Attorney" Paul Madriani appears in several legal thrillers by this lawyer-turned-author
Ben Franklin went to London in 1757 to represent this colony's assembly
This publication that Ben first put out in 1732 often sold 10,000 copies a year
In 1783 Franklin asked Congress to recall him from this country; he finally made it home in 1785
Current events of 1751 included the appearance of Ben's scientific work "Experiments and Observations on" this
The Hutchinson Letters scandal got Ben fired as deputy this in 1774
Name shared by a Sauk chief famous for his war & a U.S. military helicopter
This "Golden Girl" had her own show in 1958 & 1977 & in 1999 became part of the cast of "Ladies Man"
People have asked why the whole airplane isn't made out of the same material as this "indestructible" device
John Archibald Wheeler coined this term in the '60s for a collapsed star so dense, no light can escape it
Famous landmark composed of chalk in the county of Kent in England
In 1958 this country launched its second 5-year plan, called "The Great Leap Forward"
In 960 Mieczyslaw I became the first ruler of this country
In 1526 he greeted an Inca nobleman on his ship, but conquest would have to wait a few years until funds were raised
In 1998 U.S. cruise missiles hit this African country in response to bombings of U.S. embassies
This 1904-1905 war began in Manchuria & ended with the battle of Tsushima Strait
About 80,000 Scots still speak the Scottish version of this ancient Celtic language
Ben More, Ben Alder & Ben Macdui are not people but tall ones of these in Scotland
Defeated at Dunsinane by Malcolm in 1054, he wasn't dethroned until killed by Malcolm in 1057
The Church of Scotland, the country's national church, is a branch of this Christian denomination
Hundreds of years old, the de facto national flag features this saint's cross

rounds.text: The 1995, 2003 & 2006 winners for Best Actor all appeared in this 1982 teen comedy
